description:
Clostridium aquiflavi is an anaerobic, spore-forming, Gram-positive bacterium that was isolated from a wastewater treatment plant in Japan. It is a motile, rod-shaped organism that measures approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 2.0-6.0 μm in length.

The bacterium is able to grow at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 45°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 37°C. It can tolerate a wide pH range, growing well between pH 6.0 and 8.0.

Clostridium aquiflavi is able to utilize a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, sucrose, and starch, as carbon and energy sources. The fermentation of these substrates results in the production of acetate, butyrate, and hydrogen as major end-products.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has placed Clostridium aquiflavi within the Clostridium cluster XIVa, which includes several other species known to be involved in the degradation of complex organic matter in anaerobic environments.

The ecological role and potential biotechnological applications of Clostridium aquiflavi are still under investigation, but its ability to thrive in wastewater treatment systems suggests it may play a role in the breakdown of organic pollutants in such environments.
